facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 21 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 21 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1961 of the Rajasthan High Court in Civil Writ No. 86 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1961 of the Rajasthan High Court in Civil Writ No. 86 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1961 of the Rajasthan High Court in Civil Writ No. 86 of 1960. C. Kasliwal Advocate General for the State of Rajasthan and M. M. Tiwari, for the appellants.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court granted certificate for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, on certificate granted by the Rajasthan High Court, raises the question of the applicability of the provisions of Chapter IV and thereby of r. 30 of the Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1955,

facts.text: Respondent obtained mining lease for extracting sandstone from certain area from Government of Rajasthan in 1956 via auction.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent obtained the mining lease for extracting sand- stone from the mines in certain area from the Government of Rajasthan in 1956. The lease was granted as a result of auction.

facts.text: Mining lease period was from April 1, 1956 to July 31, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The period of the lease was from April 1, 1956 to July 31, 1959. The respondent applied for extension of the period upto two years in view of the mandatory nature of the main provision of r. 30

facts.text: Respondent applied for extension of lease period up to two years citing r.30.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent applied for extension of the period upto two years in view of the mandatory nature of the main provision of r. 30 and Simultaneously also applied for the renewal of the lease for a further period

facts.text: Respondent applied for renewal of lease per proviso to r.30.

anchor.surface_text: and Simultaneously also applied for the renewal of the lease for a further period in accordance with the provisions of the proviso to r. 30. The first prayer was refused

facts.text: State Government refused extension up to two years.

anchor.surface_text: The first prayer was refused and the State Government extended the period of the lease at first by six months and later by another two months.

facts.text: State Government extended lease by six months then another two months.

anchor.surface_text: and the State Government extended the period of the lease at first by six months and later by another two months. The respondent thereafter filed a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereafter filed a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court and prayed for issue of a writ of mandamus directing the striking down of the order

facts.text: In writ, respondent prayed for mandamus to strike down 8-month renewal order.

anchor.surface_text: in the High Court and prayed for issue of a writ of mandamus directing the striking down of the order of the Government renewing the lease for 8 months and directing the State of Rajasthan further to extend the lease

facts.text: Writ prayed for extension of lease for two years from July 30, 1959 per r.30.

anchor.surface_text: directing the State of Rajasthan further to extend the lease in the first instance for two years from July 30. 1959 to bring, it unconformity with the period of lease specified in r. 30 and to renew.

facts.text: Writ prayed for renewal after extended period for 5 years under r.30.

anchor.surface_text: with the period of lease specified in r. 30 and to renew. after the expiry of such extended period, for a further period of 5 years under r. 30 of the rules.

facts.text: State contested that Chapter IV rules do not apply to Chapter V auction grants.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Rajasthan, appellant, companytested the petition on the ground that the provisions of Chapter IV of the rules did number apply to the grant of mining leases by auction or tender provided for by Chapter V of the rules

facts.text: State claimed initial short lease period was at respondent's desire.

anchor.surface_text: and that in any case the initial period short of 5 years must be deemed to have been at the desire of the respondent and that any further extension of the period of the lease under the proviso

facts.text: State claimed further extension under proviso is discretionary.

anchor.surface_text: was in the discretion of the Government and companysequently, the respondent companyld number claim to have the period of the lease extended for a period of 5 years.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court held Chapter IV applicable to Chapter V grants as far as possible.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the provisions of Chapter IV of the rules were applicable as far as possible to the grant of mining M B N  3SCI-13 leases by auction under Chapter V.

facts.text: High Court held shorter lease period deemed at respondent's request.

anchor.surface_text: that though the State Government had to give a lease for 5 years in view of r. 30, yet the shorter period of the lease in favour of the respondent must, in the circumstances, be deemed to have been at his request

facts.text: High Court held respondent entitled to 5-year extension per proviso.

anchor.surface_text: and that the respondent was entitled to an extension of the lease by a further period of 5 years in accordance with the provisions of the proviso.

facts.text: High Court directed State to renew lease for 5 years from original expiry with option for further 5 years per r.30.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore directed the State Government to renew the lease for a period of 5 years from the expiry of the original lease with option of further renewal, if so desired, by another period of 5 years subject to the companyditions mentioned in r. 30.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court on applicability of Chapter IV and construction of r.30.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the High Court has companye to a right companyclusion on these two points.

facts.text: Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1955 made by State under Central rules.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Rajasthan made the rules in 1955 in the exercise of the powers companyferred by r. 4 of the Central rules. Chapter IV of the rules deals with grant of mining leases

facts.text: Sandstone is a minor mineral under Central rules.

anchor.surface_text: Clause of r. 3 of the Central rules defined minor mineral to mean building stone etc., which admittedly included sand- stone Rule 4 stated that the rules would number apply to minor minerals

facts.text: High Court relief included option for second extension though not explicitly prayed.

anchor.surface_text: it has been argued for the State that the High Court granted relief to the respondent in excess of what he had prayed, inasmuch as the High Court had directed the Government to renew the respondents first lease

issues.text: whether the provisions of Chapter IV of the rules govern the grant of mining leases by auction under the provisions of Chapter V of the rules

holdings.text: The High Court has come to a right conclusion on the applicability of Chapter IV including r.30 to grants under Chapter V and on the construction of r.30.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the High Court has come to a right conclusion on these two points. Section 5 of the Mines and Minerals Regulation and Develop- ment Act, 1948 Act LIII of 1948 empowered the Central Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court's holdings on key issues after stating questions.

holdings.text: The contention that the rules under Chapter IV do not apply to mining leases granted under Chapter V is not sound and the High Court rightly held that they do apply so far as applicable to mining leases granted under Chapter V.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the contention that the rules under Chapter IV do not apply to mining leases granted under Chapter V is not sound and that the High Court rightly held that they do apply so far as applicable to mining leases granted tinder Chapter V. Rule 30 deals with the period of lease.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: Ch IV heading general, covers essential incidents not in Ch V; specific rules like 19,26,27,29,31,32 apply; no express exclusion.

holdings.text: Rule 30 deals with the period of lease and applies to leases granted under Chapter V both because the rules under Chapter IV apply to such leases and because there is no corresponding rule in Chapter V.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 30 deals with the period of lease. This rule will apply to leases granted under Chapter V both because the rules under Chapter IV apply to such leases and because there is no corresponding rule in Chapter V.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from general applicability of Ch IV; no specific rule in Ch V for lease period.

holdings.text: The word may in the main provision of the rule must mean shall and make the provision mandatory. Government must fix the period of the lease at 5 years in the absence of any expression of desire by the applicant for taking the lease for a shorter period.

anchor.surface_text: The word may in the main provision of the rule must mean shall and make the provision mandatory. This is obvious from the last portion of the provision. If the State Government had discretion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual interpretation: last portion makes shorter period only if applicant desires; otherwise mandatory 5 years.

holdings.text: The word may in the proviso in regard to the extension of the period by Government should also be construed as shall so as to make it incumbent on Government to extend the period of the lease if the lessee desires extension.

anchor.surface_text: The word may in the proviso in regard to the extension of the period by Government should also be construed as shall so as to make it incumbent on Government to extend the period of the lease if the lessee desires extension. Of course no question for the extension of the lease can arise if the lessee himself does not wish

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive: lessee's option requires mandatory extension if desired; word 'may' due to option.

holdings.text: The first extension has to be for five years. Government has no option in that regard as well.

anchor.surface_text: The first extension has to be for five years. Government has no option in that regard as well. This appears from what is provided in connection with the option of the lessee for a second extension.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second extension equivalent to first; guarantee within 3 years implies first extension at least 5 years.

holdings.text: The High Court is right in holding that the respondents taking the lease for a period upto July 31, 1959 must amount to his expressing a desire for having a lease for that period.

anchor.surface_text: We are further of opinion that the High Court is right in holding that the respondents taking the lease for a period upto July 31, 1959 must amount to his expressing a desire for having a lease for that period. If he did not so desire, he need not have bid and taken the lease for the period for which it was to be given by auction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: By bidding and taking shorter lease via auction, respondent expressed desire for that period.

holdings.text: The contention is not sound [that High Court granted relief in excess of prayer].

anchor.surface_text: The contention is not sound. The relief claimed after the expiry of the period of the first lease, which, according to the respondent, was also to be extended by two years, reads and then, after the expiry of the period of five years the lease be renewed for a period of five years under Rule 30 ,of Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1955.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prayer for renewal under r.30 includes option as per rule; court competent to direct accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the High Court has companye to a right companyclusion on these two points.
